nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based teacher evaluation can improve teacher effectiveness in lasting ways beyond selection and incentive mechanisms
We use a quasi-experimental design exploiting phased-in timing of Cincinnati Public Schools TES evaluations for mid-career 4th-8th grade math teachers hired 1993–1999 to identify evaluation effects

TES program: year-long observation-based evaluation with three peer observations and one administrator observation, rubric-based scores, written feedback, and final domain scores with modest formal stakes

Empirical model: teacher fixed effects regression of student standardized end-of-year math scores on indicators for year of evaluation and years after, controlling for experience (capped quadratic), student covariates, and grade-by-year fixed effects

Identification assumption: timing of scheduled evaluation (phase-in by hire year) is as-good-as-random conditional on controls, so within-teacher before-during-after comparisons identify causal effects absent differential time-varying assignment

Data: merged CPS administrative data on TES participation, observation dates and scores, teacher characteristics, and student prior and outcome standardized math test scores for 105 teachers and 14,331 student-year observations (2003–2010)
TES provides individualized feedback via rubric-scored observations and peer evaluators, which plausibly supplies new performance information and fosters skill development or sustained effort

Main estimate: students taught in years after a teacher's TES evaluation score on average 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than when taught by the same teacher before evaluation (statistically significant)
Observed balance checks and event-study analyses show little evidence that observable student or teacher characteristics or preexisting within-teacher trends explain the postevaluation gains

Heterogeneity: postevaluation gains are larger for teachers with low pre-TES value-added, low TES scores, and teachers whose TES scores grew most during evaluation; gains larger for math specialists than for self-contained teachers

Robustness: results persist when using scheduled (phase-in) evaluation year, instrumenting actual timing with scheduled timing (2SLS), alternative experience specifications, and restricting to teachers observed before and after evaluation
Reading outcomes: no statistically significant TES effects on reading achievement, consistent with smaller teacher-driven variation in reading

Cost and scale considerations: TES program cost ~7500 dollars per evaluated teacher per year (mostly evaluator salaries) and peer evaluators' opportunity cost may offset some gains but net productivity tradeoffs compare favorably under plausible assumptions

Limitations and caveats: mechanisms cannot be definitively identified from available data, results pertain to mid-career math teachers in Cincinnati and may be smaller where regular feedback exists, and attrition could attenuate estimates though analyses suggest attrition does not drive results

Conclusion: well-structured subjective teacher evaluation can produce lasting improvements in teacher effectiveness via information-based skill development or sustained effort, implying evaluations can serve as professional development in addition to sorting
